sen.j: 勅語（ちょくご）とは、原則として天皇が口頭により発する公務上の意思表示であり、詔勅の一種である。
sen.e: Chokugo (imperial ordinance) means, in principle, the Emperor's verbal expression of his or her intention concerning official matters; it is one of Shochoku (imperial rescript).
Chokugo means, in principle, the Emperor's verbal expression of his or her intention concerning official matters, and is a type of Shochoku (imperial rescript).
Chokugo means, in principle, the Emperor's verbal expression of his or her intention concerning official matters, and is a type of Shochoku (imperial rescript).

sen.j: 主に明治時代から日本国憲法が施行される前に出され続けた。
sen.e: Mainly Chokugo had continuously been issued from the Meiji Period until the Constitution of Japan was enforced.
Chokugo had continuously been issued mainly since the Meiji Period before enforcement of the Constitution of Japan.
Chokugo had continuously been issued mainly since the Meiji Period before enforcement of the Constitution of Japan.

sen.j: 現在では「お言葉」と呼ぶことが普通である。
sen.e: It is currently called as 'o-kotoba' (the word) in general.
Today it is called as 'o-kotoba' (a combination of 'o' as a honorific prefix to be applied before noun or verb and 'kotoba' meaning words) in general.
sen.cmt: 補足事項を修正しました
sen.e: Today it is called as 'o-kotoba' (a combination of 'o' as a honorific prefix to be applied before noun or verb and 'kotoba' meaning words) in general.

sen.j: もともとは中国で皇帝の意思表示を勅と呼んだことに由来する。
sen.e: Chokugo is originated from the fact that the expression of Emperor's intention was called as Choku in China.
The term Chokugo originated from the fact that the expression of Emperor's intention (imperial decree) had been called Choku (written as "勅" in Chinese) in China.
sen.cmt: 表現を修正し、曖昧さ回避のため補足しました
sen.e: The term Chokugo originated from the fact that the expression of Emperor's intention (imperial decree) had been called Choku (written as "勅" in Chinese) in China.

sen.j: 勅語を書面に写したものを勅語書という。
sen.e: The script of Chokugo on paper is Chokugo-sho.
The written Chokugo is called Chokugo-sho (literally, documented imperial decree).
sen.cmt: 表現を修正し、補足しました
sen.e: The written Chokugo is called Chokugo-sho (literally, documented imperial decree).

sen.j: 勅語書に天皇の親署や国務大臣の副署はない。
sen.e: On Chokugo-sho, there is no signature by Emperor himself or herself and no countersignature by the Minister of State.
The Chokugo-sho do not include any signature affixed by Emperor in his or her own hand or any countersignature by Minister of State.
sen.cmt: 表現を修正し、補足しました
sen.e: The Chokugo-sho do not include any signature affixed by Emperor in his or her own hand or any countersignature by Minister of State.

sen.j: ただし、教育勅語は例外であり、書面により発し、天皇の親署がある（国務大臣の副署はない）。
sen.e: However, it is exceptional in case of Kyoiku Chokugo (Imperial Ordinance on Education) issued in writing and signed by Emperor himself with no countersignature by the Minister of State.
However, Kyoiku Chokugo (Imperial Rescript on Education) is an exception, which is issued in writing and signed by Emperor himself or herself (without countersignature by Minister of State).
sen.cmt: 用語・表現・形式を修正しました。教育勅語定訳参考：http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/283947/Imperial-Rescript-on-Education
sen.e: However, Kyoiku Chokugo (Imperial Rescript on Education) is an exception, which is issued in writing and signed by Emperor himself or herself (without countersignature by Minister of State).

sen.j: 大日本帝国憲法下の勅語には、帝国議会の開院式に発せられるのをはじめ、「青少年学徒ニ賜リタル勅語」など様々なものがある。
sen.e: Various Chokugo was issued under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan such as the one at the opening ceremony of imperial Diet, or the one titled as 'Chokugo deigned to juveniles and students', etc.
